item.title: About
item.dc:creator: RyanAchten
item.content:encoded:
Hiko is a digital writing and publishing platform developed for Victoria University of Wellington. Hiko was produced out of a need to allow students to create individual and collaborative texts that were interactive, co-creative and media-rich, without requiring specialist coding skills. The initial system requirements for Hiko included the following:
  • Creation of born-digital texts using rich text, Markdown or HTML
  • Creation of individual projects
  • Creation of collaborative projects
  • Ability to peer-review work (review, comment, and critique work of others)
  • Ability to archive work using a version management system
  • Ability to manage workflow between primary evidence, research and publication
  • Multimodal media integration
  • Online student portfolio
  • Software created using open sources
WordPress’ CMS was eventually selected for its plugin ecosystem, ease of which rapid development could take place, and the degree to which project requirements were fulfilled by WordPress core out-of-the-box. Both the frontend and backend of WordPress were heavily customised and a number of plugins used to deliver the end result. Of all of the features we have built for Hiko, two are of specific importance: Hiko’s article types and editorial workflow.

Article Types

Hiko provides authors with the option to create digital works in the form of three different types of articles:

Blog Posts

Are articles which may be used for short-form textual pieces – be it a social media announcement, poetry, or short story.

Projects

These are the primary medium of the Hiko platform; you may use Projects for any written purpose; essays, creative works, scholarly articles – the choice is yours.

Series

Are collections of Blog Posts, Projects and even other Series which are connected to a central theme. These may be also used to produce works comprised of multiple parts, such as zines, essay collections or periodicals.

Editorial Workflow

To ensure that only the highest quality work can be viewed on the Hiko platform, Hiko has adopted an editorial workflow, where an author must have their work approved by an editor before it will become publicly accessible. This workflow is comprised of the following stages:

Draft

The draft stage refers to any article you are currently writing and have not yet submitted for review (think work in progress). When you are satisfied with the article, you can submit it for review by an editor.

Pending

Once you have submitted your work for review by an editor, they may either consider it ready to be published or identify issues and send it back to you for further revisions (where the article will once again become a Draft).

Published

Any articles an editor feels is ready to become publicly accessible will be published. Once published, you can share your work with others and add it to your portfolio via your Profile.

Credits

Design and development: Ryan Achten Supervision:
  • Dr Cherie Lacey
  • Dr Sydney Shep
  • Walter Langelaar
  • Matt Plummer
Developed for Victoria University of Wellington, 2017-2018

item.title: Author Tutorial
item.dc:creator: RyanAchten
item.content:encoded:
Getting Setup

Before we get into writing some actual content using the Hiko system, we’re going to spend a few minutes showing you how to get your account and details setup.

Logging into Hiko

  • Log into the Hiko system by clicking on the Log In button - this will redirect you to the login screen.
  • At the login screen, enter your email or username and password associated with you Hiko account. If you are unsure as to what these details are, click the Lost your password? link or get in contact with your system administrator.

Customising Your Profile

  • Once you’re logged in, one of the first things we’re going to take a look is setting up your Profile. If you’re not redirected to the Dashboard page automatically, you can access this using the Home button above (or go there directly using the Profile button).
  • From the Dashboard page, we can access our Profile page via the Profile link on the sidebar menu.
  • At the Profile page, we can decide how our profile and portfolio appears to the public and other users of the Hiko system. The website field refers to your own personal website - you can leave this blank if you want.
  • Feel free to customise this how you see fit and scroll down and click Update Profile to confirm your changes. Don’t worry about the Featured Posts, Projects and Series at this stage; we’ll come back to that once we’ve got some work to show.

Accessing Your Dashboard

The Dashboard is the landing page you may have been redirected to earlier after logging in. Here you are able to see the current status of your various articles. Before we get into actually creating some articles of our own, it might be a good idea to introduce some key concepts underlying the Hiko system.

Types of articles

In the image above we can see three rows dedicated to the different types of articles Hiko allows for: Blog Posts, Projects and Series Blog Posts Are articles which may be used for short-form textual pieces - be it a social media announcement, poetry, or short story. Try to keep your blog posts to under 500 words; if you find yourself exceeding this, perhaps a Project, would be a more appropriate medium. Projects These are the primary medium of the Hiko platform; you may use Projects for any written purpose; essays, creative works, scholarly articles - the choice is yours. Series Are collections of Blog Posts, Projects and even other Series which are connected to a central theme. These may be also used to produce works comprised of multiple parts, such as zines, essay collections or periodicals.

Editorial Workflow

  • Within the rows of different types of articles, you will also be able to see three column headings: Drafted, Pending, and Published. These each refer to various parts of Hiko’s editorial workflow authors use to publish their work.
  1. Draft
    • The draft stage refers to any article you are currently writing and have not yet submitted for review (think work in progress). When you are satisfied with the article, you can submit it for review by an editor.
  2. Pending
    • Once you have submitted your work for review by an editor, they may either consider it ready to be published or identify issues and send it back to you for further revisions (where the article will once again become a Draft).
  3. Published
    • Any articles an editor feels is ready to become publicly accessible will be published. Once published, you can share your work with others and add it to your portfolio via your Profile.
Now that you’ve got a feel for how Hiko works, let's get into some actual writing.

Creating a Blog Post

  • The first type of article we’re going to start off with is a Blog Post. Let’s navigate there by hovering over the Posts icon and clicking on Add New.

Editor Overview

  • Before we get writing, let’s go over what the various boxes refer to. Fortunately, these are largely the same across all of the types of articles available in Hiko.
    • Title - title of the post
    • Editor - used for writing the bulk of the content of the post; we’ll talk about this later
    • Citations - be sure to include here any references to external sources or media you may have used during the creation of your post. Be sure to check with your editor as to the style guide you are expected to follow here (i.e. APA, MLA, etc.).
    • Publish - here is where you can see the status of your post and, when it is ready, submit it for review by an editor.
    • Featured Image - click on this link to upload a header image relevant to the premise of your post.
      • Ideally these images should be of good resolution (at least 1000px wide and 500px high).
      • Be sure to comply with copyright restrictions when selecting images you have not produced (see our Media Guide for creative common sources).
      • Note: to make sure your article looks great, a featured image is required before you are able to submit for review.
    • Courses - be sure to include any academic courses this post was produced as part of.
    • Categories - if you feel that this post aligns with any of the categories provided, you can add them to aid discoverability.
    • Tags - Similar to tags (or ‘keywords’) serve to aid discoverability and aid contextualisation of the post.
Now that we know what the various boxes and buttons do, feel free to go ahead and write your first Blog Post. Once you’re satisfied with your work, go ahead and submit it for review. If you ever want to go back and edit a previous post, check its status, or view all of your posts at once, you can access this by clicking the All Posts sidebar link.

Creating a Project

Since we have mastered the basics of writing with the Hiko system, we’re now going to go over creating a Project. The functionality for Projects is largely the same as what we just covered in our Blog Post section, however, there are some areas we glossed over or specific to Projects which we will discuss in this section.

Writing Modes

  • Hover over Projects and click Add New where you will be redirected to a screen similar to the one we worked with during the Blog Post tutorial.
  • The editor which you wrote the bulk of your Blog Post in previously is actually capable of different writing modes:

Rich Text

  • Rich text is the default mode activated when you land on an Add New page. If you’ve ever used a word processor, such as Microsoft Word or Google Docs, you may find this quite similar.
    • Rich text allows you to use the editor’s toolbar to control the presentation of your text.
    • Common keyboard shortcuts, such crtl+b / cmd+b are also supported here (depending on your computer’s operating system).

Markdown

  • By swapping to the Text tab of the editor (Visual being reserved for rich text), you can begin to work in a form of markup language called Markdown. Markdown is a popular method of writing on the internet, as your writing is no longer impeded by clicking buttons or your hands leaving the keyboard. If you’ve ever written on platforms such as Medium, you may be familiar with this approach.
    • The Markdown syntax is too big to discuss in the context of this tutorial. Check out our Writing Guides page for handy resources on the topic.

HTML

  • The Text tab of the editor allows for another markup language: the Hypertext Markup Language, or simply ‘HTML’. HTML provides the scaffolding for websites on the internet, so it is certainly useful to understand. While slightly more complex than Markdown, the syntax for HTML has a very low learning curve.
    • Similar to Markdown, the syntax for HTML exceeds the scope of this tutorial. Refer to our Writing Guides for further information.
    • Nerd Note: JavaScript is escaped and rendered as plain text for security reasons. Inline CSS, however, is largely supported.

Excerpt

A feature somewhat important to Projects and Series (which we will be covering soon) is an Excerpt. An excerpt acts as a foreword to the article you have written, to help entice readers to engage with your material. If you’re writing a scholarly article, a short abstract could also be included here.
  • You should be able to see this box below the editor; if not, go to the Screen Options dropdown and click the appropriate checkbox (excerpts can be enabled in the same manner for Blog Posts).

Collaboration

Requesting a co-author

  • Creativity through collaboration is an important aspect of the Hiko platform. If you want to work alongside a friend or colleague on this Project, add any initial content you want to start the article with and save it as a draft (via the Save Draft button). Be sure to add important information such as a title and courses to make it easier for your editor to find.
  • Once you’re satisfied, contact your editor with: (*required)
    • *The name of the Hiko user you would like to collaborate with
    • *The type of article (_Blog Post_, _Project_, or _Series_)
    • *The title of your article you would like them to co-author
    • Any courses the article is associated with
  • Note: before sending your request, be sure to save your draft and exit out of the article. If you are writing when the editor attempts to add a co-author, you may be kicked off the article; the article should automatically save- however, it is better to be safe than sorry.
  • If you see the warning ‘Name of editor is currently editing’ above your article in All Posts/Projects/Series - avoid editing the article; they are probably adding your co-author, or reviewing your work.
  • Once you see your co-author listed as an Author of the article, you will know that your collaborator has been successfully added.
  • Note: collaborators on the Hiko system can’t simultaneously edit the same document.
    • If this is a necessary aspect of your workflow, consider writing the bulk of the article using a platform such as Google Docs and pasting content into Hiko.
    • If a user is currently editing a document you are a co-author on, you will be able to tell from the All Posts/Projects/Series page.
    • In the event you need to access the document, regardless of a peer having the document open, click on the Edit link anyway. You will then be prompted with the following message. It should be safe to press Take Over as the author’s work will be saved automatically.
  • Note: articles that you have not created yourself but are collaborating on will appear under the All tab, as opposed to the Mine tab which you are presented by default.

Communication

  • You can communicate ideas and suggestions to your collaborators directly inside of the Hiko system without resorting to third-party systems. Simply locate the Editorial Comments section at the bottom of the Add New page and click Respond to this Post.
  • Additionally, this same system can be used to communicate with editors, who may use these comments to suggest changes and ideas prior to the article’s publication.

Revisions

  • There may come a time where you or your collaborators have made changes to your article which you no longer feel are appropriate. In these situations, you can use the Revision tool to compare and contrast changes made to the document and restore previous versions of the article.
    • To do so, click the Browse link next to the Revisions section of the Publish box.
    • You will then be presented with a screen where new content is highlighted in green, while any removed content is highlighted in red (unchanged content has no background).
    • You can slide through various changes to the document using the slider at the top of the page and restore them using the Restore This Revision button.

Creating a Series

The final type of article Hiko provides are Series; using Series we can create articles comprised of multiple articles centred around a theme or topic.

Series Components

  • Hover over Series and click Add New where you will be redirected to a screen similar to the one we working with in the other tutorials.
  • Using the editor, we can provide the body content of the Series; perhaps to discuss its premise, or to add content unique to the Series.
  • In fact, all of the fields are exactly the same as those available for a Project, with one major addition:
    • Using the Series Components panel, we can add the various Blog Posts, Projects, or even other Series which comprise this Series. The list to left are the articles we are able to add, while the (empty) list to the right are the Series components.
    • To add a component, we can hover over one of the items in the list and press the + button
    • To remove a component, we can hover over the item again and select the - button
    • We can reorder these components by hovering over one of the items and drag-and-dropping it in place.
    • Later, when we have produced a lot of different articles, it may become cumbersome to simply scroll and find what you’re looking for. In this case, we can simply filter by article type or search for the title of the desired article
    • Note: only articles on which we are an author or co-author are available for us to add to a series.
      • Additionally, only articles which are published will be published along with the article, however, unpublished Series components can still be submitted for review.

Including Media

Be it a video, an image or a map, the majority of media out there is able to be integrated into a Blog Post, Project, or Series by Hiko in one form or another. This is especially important in Projects and Series, where multimedia works are encouraged. Depending on the type of media you are wanting to integrate into your works, there are one of two approaches.

Images

  • Images can be inserted directly into an article via Hiko’s Media Library, via the Add Media button. Here you can upload or add existing media up to 5MB in size.

Anything else

  • Anything other than images need to be embedded using third-party providers (i.e. Youtube or Vimeo for video or Google Maps for maps). See our Media Guide for further information about supported embeds.
    • While some embeds will work if copied and pasted into the editor using the rich text Visual mode, a safer approach is to paste the embed snippet using the Text mode:
    • Once the embed snippet has been pasted, you can switch back to Visual to see the rendered result:
You should be pretty familiar with the other boxes present in the Add New screen, so go forth and create your first Series and, when you’re ready, submit it to review by your editor. Once your editor has published a Blog Post, Project, or Series, meet back with us at the next tutorial for some final notes.

Final Notes

We’ve pretty much gone over the majority of Hiko’s system in the previous tutorials. We’ll finish this tutorial with a few bits and pieces you might find useful.

Setting Up Your Portfolio

  • Once you’ve produced some amazing articles in Hiko that have been reviewed and published by your editor, you may want to be able to show off to friends, family, colleagues and potential employers your body of work.
  • To get this done, head to the Profile page via the link on the sidebar.
  • We looked at the Featured Posts, Projects and Series sections briefly at the start of the tutorial when we were customising our profile. Now that we’ve got some work to feature, let’s look at how to use them.

Featured Posts

  • Having completed the Series tutorial, you will probably recognise the lists we used to select our Series Components; in fact, the process is pretty much exactly the same.
    • Hovering over an article in the list allows us to add it to those which will be featured on our profile page. We can add up to four Blog Posts, Projects and Series to promote on our portfolio.
    • By hovering over those in the right column, we can drag-and-drop to rearrange them to taste.
    • Once you’re satisfied with the articles you want to feature, be sure to click the Update Profile button to confirm your changes.

  • If you want to see how you’re portfolio is looking, or if you want to share it with others, you can access this directly via your Profile page at the View Portfolio link.

  • This will redirect you to your publicly accessible portfolio, now updated with your work.

item.title: Editor Manual
item.dc:creator: RyanAchten
item.content:encoded:
What’s an Editor?

Hiko has a hierarchical editorial workflow (discussed further below) used to help manage the production of content through the system. Your role as an editor comes with a couple of responsibilities:
  • Reviewing Articles - deciding which articles are suitable for publication and those which warrant further revisions
  • Aiding Collaboration - authors are not able to add collaborators to their works; it is up to you to decide if co-authorship is suitable and facilitate these arrangements
  • Managing Courses - if Hiko is being used in an educational context, courses are available to aid categorisation of works
  • Managing Categories - there may be other terms, specific perhaps to a certain task or theme of work, required to group works under. You may do so by creating a category

  • One task you are not able to do is add new users to the Hiko system; to achieve this, get in contact with your system administrator

What about Authors?

In addition to the privileges editors receive in the Hiko system, they are also able to do everything authors are able to. To get a feel for how authors are expected to use the Hiko system, feel free to read and even complete the Author Tutorial.

Getting Started

Logging into Hiko

  • Log into the Hiko system by clicking on the Log In button - this will redirect you to the login screen
  • At the login screen, enter your email or username and password associated with you Hiko account. If you are unsure as to what these details are, click the Lost your password? link or get in contact with your system administrator.

Reviewing Articles

Editorial Workflow

Before an author can have their Blog Post, Project, or Series become publicly accessible, the article needs to be reviewed and accepted by an editor such as yourself. This process is part of Hiko’s editorial workflow, which comprises the following stages:
  1. Draft
    • The draft stage refers to any article an author is currently writing and has not yet submitted for review (think work in progress). When the author is satisfied with the article, they may submit it to you for review.
  2. Pending
    • Once an author has submitted their work for review, you may either consider it ready to be published or identify issues and send it back to the author for further revisions (where the article will once again become a Daft).
  3. Published
    • Any articles you feel are ready to become publicly accessible can be published. Once published, an author may share their work with others and add it to their portfolio.

Reviewing an Article

  • Articles pending review by yourself and other editors can be viewed at the All Post page. Regardless of the type of article (Blog Post, Project, or Series), the process is the same.
  • Once on the All Posts page, you can find the articles awaiting review by clicking the Pending link
    • In the case that you are looking for a specific article, you can use the search field to filter by the title of an article
  • By clicking on an article you would like to review, you will be presented with the content of the article. If you deem the article to be fit for publication, the article can be published by clicking the Publish button

Requesting Changes

If there are changes to be made to the article before it can be published, you can communicate issues or comments to the author in a couple of ways:
  • One 'non-invasive' approach is to use the internal commenting system Hiko provides. Find the Editorial Comments section at the bottom of the page and click Respond to this Post. Comments themselves can be responded to by hovering over the comment in question.
  • There may be cases where this commenting is too indirect for effective communication. For example, in the case where you want to comment on a specific line of text, writing comments inline maybe more effective.
    • Be sure to be clear where these comments have been made - changing the colour of the text to something obvious might be a good idea
  • You will also want to change the status of the article back to Draft to allow the author to re-submit once they have made the appropriate alterations. To do so, click the Edit link next to the Status field in the Publish box.
    • Select Draft from the dropdown and press OK
    • Press Save the Draft to save your changes and exit the article to make the article accessible to its author

Adding a Co-Author

For a co-author to another author’s article (be it a Blog Post, Project, or Series), the creator of the project needs to contact you with the following information: (*required)
  • *The name of the Hiko user you would like to collaborate with
  • *The type of article (_Blog Post, Project_, or _Series_)
  • *The title of your article you would like them to co-author
  • Depending on the type of article you can then navigate to All Posts/Projects/Series (in this example the request is for a collaborative Project)
    • Search the name of the article, filter by author name, or by course (if supplied) to find the article in question
  • Once you have located the article, hover over the article and click the Edit link
  • If an author is currently editing the article, you will be prompted with the following message. It should be safe to press Take Over as the author’s work will be saved automatically
  • Locate the Authors box at the bottom of the page and begin typing the name of the author to be added as a co-author. When the appropriate name is presented, click the link to confirm the addition
  • Important: once the necessary co-authors have been added, be sure to click the Save Draft button in the Publish box at the top of the page. Exit out of the article screen once you have completed the additions (to prevent the article appearing ‘locked’).

Managing Courses

Adding a Course

  • To add a course, simply hover over one of the Posts, Projects, or Series options on the sidebar menu and click on the link Courses. It doesn’t matter which article type this is done through - the course which is created will be available for all types of article.
  • You will then be redirected to the Courses management page, containing a series of fields.
    • A good rule of thumb when creating courses is being consistent to help ensure intuitive user experience. Some guidelines for these fields are discussed below:
      • Name: name of the course. The naming structure adopted here is the course code followed by the title of the paper.
      • Slug: reference code for accessing the course.
        • Important: this must be URL friendly, containing no spaces or ampersands. Underscores and hyphens are recommended for separating characters.
      • Parent Course: ignore, this is irrelevant for most use cases.
      • Description: description of the course. Keep this concise and clear.
  • When you are satisfied with the course details, go ahead and click Add new Course

Editing a Course

  • To edit the details of a course, simply hover over the course in question and click the edit link
  • You will then be redirected to the Edit Course page, where you can modify the necessary details. Once you are satisfied, click the Update button

Removing a Course

  • To remove a course, simply hover over the course to be removed and select Delete

Managing Categories

The process for managing categories is exactly the same as the approach we just discussed for managing courses.
  • To access the category page, simply hover over one of the Posts, Projects, or Series options on the sidebar menu and click on the link Categories. Again, it doesn’t matter which article type this is done through - the course which is created will be available for all types of article.
To avoid repetition, follow the steps described in Managing Courses for adding, editing and removing categories

item.title: Admin Manual
item.dc:creator: RyanAchten
item.content:encoded:
What’s an Admin?

Hiko’s system administrator sits outside of its editorial workflow, ensuring that the system is functioning appropriately and performing managerial tasks. As an admin, you have access to the highest degree of administrative features and are therefore responsible for a few important tasks:
  • Managing Users: users cannot simply sign up to the Hiko system. Instead, they have to be invited by admins such as yourself
  • Updating WordPress: Hiko is built on the WordPress content management system, the core of which occasionally needs updating
  • Updating Plugins: in addition to WordPress, Hiko relies on a number of important plugins to operate properly, these also need updating on occasion
  • Updating Page Content: updating content on Hiko’s main pages (i.e About, Legal, etc.)
  • Featured Article: on the Hiko landing page, one article may be used for the main splash
We’ve also included some helpful additional resources at the end which may come in handy.

Getting Started

Logging into Hiko

  • Log into the Hiko system by clicking on the ‘Log In’ button - this will redirect you to the login screen
  • At the login screen, enter your email or username and password associated with you Hiko account. If you are unsure as to what these details are, click the Lost your password? link

Managing Users

The main user task you will have to deal with as an admin is setting up user accounts with their necessary information. Additionally, administrators are responsible for other user-related tasks such as modifying user login information where required and removing users from the Hiko system.

Adding New Users

  • To add a new user, we first need to hover over the Users section on the sidebar menu and select Add New User
  • You will then be redirected to the Add New User screen, providing a number of fields required for the creation of a new user account. Try to keep your approach to user information as consistent as possible across all users.
    • Username - used for login purposes. Following existing conventions, such as school logins might be best practice here.
    • Email - also used for login purposes. Again, using school emails addresses could be a good idea in terms of stability.
    • First Name - self-explanatory
    • Last Name - self-explanatory
    • Website - as an admin, you don’t need to add this; authors can add their own at a later time
    • Password - Important: a secure password is generated by default, which users can later customise. If you want to provide a standardised password, ensure security is considered ‘Strong’
    • Role - Important: by default, this is set to Author. Change using the dropdown to Editor or Administrator if appropriate. These roles can be briefly defined as:
    • Administrator – somebody who has access to all the administration features within a single site.
    • Editor – somebody who can publish and manage the posts of other users.
    • Author – somebody who can create their own posts but not publish.
    • Featured Posts / Projects / Series - ignore; this is for student to update later as they produce their own works.
  • When you are satisfied with the user information you have entered, you can go ahead and confirm this addition by clicking the Add New User button at the bottom of the screen.

Editing User Information

  • The information discussed above can be changed at any time via the All Users page
  • You will then be redirected to the All Users page. Here you will need to locate the user whose information you would like to edit (users can be searched for, or filtered by role). Hover over the user in question and click the Edit link

Removing Users

  • Sometimes users may no longer be using the Hiko system and need to be removed. To do so, simply access the All Users scene discussed above and hover over the user in question. Click the Delete link.
  • You will then be presented with a screen asking what Hiko should do with the deleted user’s content. Generally, you will want to click Delete all content and not attribute it to another user.\

Updating WordPress

Hiko is built on top of the WordPress content management system. WordPress is frequently updated to improve features, fix bugs, and prevent security vulnerabilities. To ensure that Hiko is secure and performant, it is important that its WordPress core is kept up-to-date. Fortunately, the process is remarkably simple:
  • You will first be notified that an update is available through an alert in the dashboard
    • Click the link Please Update Now or select Updates from the sidebar menu
  • This will redirect you to the WordPress Updates page. Click the button Update Now to proceed with the installation
  • While you see the following scene, WordPress is being updated
  • When the installation is complete, you will see the following screen
Important: while every measure has been taken to ensure Hiko’s stability, WordPress updates can introduce factors we were unable to foresee at the time of Hiko’s development. If you, or any of your users, notice anything strange occurring after a WordPress update, please log a bug via our GitHub repository.

Updating Plugins

In addition to using WordPress as its core, Hiko relies on a number of plugins to function as expected. These plugins are also often updated, sometimes in response to WordPress updating, to improve existing functionality, or introduce new features. As an admin, you will also be responsible for making sure that Hiko’s plugins are also up-to-date. Similar, to updating the WordPress core, the process is very simple.
  • You will be able to see if any plugins require updating when a red circle appears next to the Plugins section on the sidebar. Hover over the link and select Installed Plugins
  • You will then be redirected to the Plugins page. The plugin(s) requiring an update will appear with a yellow alert below their description. Click the update now link
  • The alert will change to the following while the update is in progress\
  • When the update is complete, the alert should display:\

Updating Page Content

A situation may arise where you would like to be able to alter the information provided on one of Hiko’s main pages, such as About, Legal, Contact, or even one of the Help pages.
  • To do so, hover over the Pages link on the sidebar and click All Pages
  • Hover over the page you would like to edit and click the Edit link
  • Use the editor to make your necessary alterations
  • Once you are satisfied with the change you have made, press Update to confirm them

Featured Article

On the Hiko landing page, one article (Blog Post, Project, or Series) is used for the header splash. This article should be a testament to the quality of user content produced through Hiko and have a high quality featured image.
  • As an admin, you have the ability to change which article is featured here by first accessing the All Pages page\
  • Hover over the Home list item and click Edit\
  • You will see near the top of the page a section called Featured Article. Before adding a new article, you will need to remove the existing article from the column on the right. Hover over the current article and press the - button
  • Now you can use the dialogue box to filter by article type or search for an article’s title to find the work you would like to promote
  • Once you have located the article you would like to promote, hover over the list item and press the + button
  • To confirm your selection, press the Update button in the Publish box

Further Reading

Did we miss something? If so, we’ve compiled a few resources which hopefully be able to help you out. As we have mentioned throughout this manual, Hiko is built on top of WordPress, a content management system with extensive documentation and support networks. If you’re interested in learning more about WordPress, or we’ve overlooked something you need, take a look at Getting Started with WordPress If you have a simple question to ask, the following forums are generally very responsive:
  • WordPress Support (various forums hosted by WordPress)
  • WordPress Stack Exchange (NB: more development orientated)

Developer Documentation

If you’re a developer and are looking to extend Hiko, take a look the ReadMe at our GitHub repository to get started If you’ve uncovered a bug, or one has been introduced through WordPress / plugin updates, you can log this bug at our GitHub issues

item.title: Writing Resources
item.dc:creator: RyanAchten
item.content:encoded:
Writing for the web

Not sure how to get started? Looking for inspiration? We’ve compiled some resources we think might be useful for you when starting out; from projects we admire, to handy tips and tricks.

E-Resources

  • ds106 (University of Mary Washington) - Resource containing tips on digital storytelling
  • 50 Tips for Writing for the Web (intechnic) - Sound advice on writing for the web
  • (Even More!) Web Content Writing Tips (contentfac) - Another good source on the topic

Books

  • ‘Writing and Editing for Digital Media’ (Carroll, 2014) - Excellent book on digital writing and editing techniques
  • ‘Crafting Digital Writing: Composing Texts Across Media and Genres’ (Hicks, 2013) - Another good book on this topic

Examples of Digital Writing Projects:

  • Bat, Bean, Beam
  • The New Inquiry
  • Public Address
  • Triple Canopy
  • Stephanie Klein
  • the f-word
  • The Blog of Disquiet
  • Reading the Maps
  • Social Dead Zone
  • Wellywood Woman

Markdown

Markdown is a popular method of writing on the internet, as your writing is no longer impeded by clicking buttons or your hands leaving the keyboard. If you’ve ever written on platforms such as Medium, you may be familiar with this approach. Excellent resources related to Markdown can be viewed at GitHub:
  • Their Mastering Markdown guide covers the majority of the syntax MD uses
  • For a quick visual reference, keep their Markdown Syntax sheet handy

HTML Resources

HTML provides the scaffolding for websites on the internet, so it is certainly useful to understand. While slightly more complex than Markdown, the syntax for HTML has a very low learning curve. If you’re interested in using HTML for writing in Hiko, a great place to start is by looking at the HTML resources provided by the Mozilla Developer Network:
  • A full list of MND HTML resources can be accessed here
  • The Introduction to HTML module is especially relevant to writing using HTML
If interactive learning comes easier to you, perhaps take a look at the codecademy Learn HTML tutorial

Citations

Chances are, if you’re creating an article as part of a university course, then a formalised reference style should be used when referencing external sources. Fortunately, Victoria University of Wellington’s library has compiled an excellent array of resources for APA, Chicago, MLA, and NZLSG. See their Referencing and Citing guide for more information.

item.title: Media Resources
item.dc:creator: RyanAchten
item.content:encoded:
WordPress Embeds

Be it a video, an image or a map, the majority of media out there is able to be integrated into a Blog Post, Project, or Series by Hiko in one form or another. Depending on the type of media you are wanting to integrate into your works, there are one of two approaches.

Images

If you’re aiming to include an image you can upload these directly to Hiko - see the section in the Author Tutorial where we go over how. If you’re looking for places to source your images from, we’ve listed some excellent repositories below.

Other media

For anything other than images need to be embedded using third-party providers (i.e. Youtube or Vimeo for video or Google Maps for maps). Hiko is built on top of the WordPress content management system to help deliver a vast array of functionality. One aspect of this functionality is the media which can be embedded into your Blog Post, Project, or Series. We briefly go over how to embed media into your articles in this section of the Author Tutorial, however, for more comprehensive guide, we recommend you take a look at the Embeds guide on WordPress.org’s Codex
  • Especially important in this guide, is the section which discusses which third-party embeds are supported by WordPress (and are therefore supported by Hiko)

Sourcing Media

When including media in your Hiko articles, we highly recommend the use of work which does not fall under restricted copyright licensing, such as those which sit in the public domain or licensed under Creative Commons. If you’re wanting to use media which falls under copyright, you will need to get in contact with the owner of the work and get their permission. While many of the sources listed below contain content free to use in your work, you need to be aware of the copyright status of the media you’re including.
  • If you’re unsure about how Creative Commons works, we suggest reading the Licences explained guide by Creative Commons NZ

Multimedia

These sources include a range of media such as images, audio, video:
  • DigitalNZ - 'Search 30+ million New Zealand items across 300+ collections in one place.’
  • Wikimedia Commons - ‘a collection of 44,455,053 freely usable media files to which anyone can contribute’
  • Internet Archive - ‘non-profit library of millions of free books, movies, software, music, websites, and more.’
  • Creative Commons Search - ‘Find content you can share, use and remix’
  • Open Culture - ‘free cultural and educational media on the web’

Images

  • Flickr Commons - ‘share hidden treasures from the world's public photography archives.’
  • Getty Search Gateway (Open Content Images) - ‘search across several of the Getty repositories, including collections databases, library catalogs, collection inventories, and archival finding aids.’

Music

  • Free Music Archive - ‘interactive library of high-quality, legal audio downloads’

TV

  • eTV - 'over 35,000 TV and Library recordings' (requires education institution login)
    • See VUW guide on how to use eTV
